text: So I'm Tim Bannister This talk is about the blackboard pattern in It's the last talk of the day We're going to wrap up after this but it's the last of the session talks Let's run with some audience interaction So for you folks what's an example of the blackboard pattern outside of kubernetes Anyone Sorry what was that LLMs I'm not sure that LLMs are like that That's more of a transformer Anyone else Anyone else want to call out Whitney Air defense you say Okay And why did you choose that Okay Why did you choose air defense Oh because you and I because you told me before Yeah okay Because we made it together We did And I'd like to thank Whitney very much for helping me make the slides here So I'm going to talk about blackboards I'm going to talk about getting to kubernetes But before we get to kubernetes it's the middle of the 20th century World War II is over and yet a cold war is just starting The superpowers fear air attack It's never been more crucial to tell if we're at peace or at war Starting from like the mid 1950s air forces especially in the West spent huge amounts of money resources on equipment and technology for air defense Huge radar installations and information systems as well Because this is where hypertext comes from It's where mice come from and the But before that they had blackboards And they had lightboards which is where the writing shows up bright So I'm talking about air defense because it's really different from kubernetes But there is a common pattern Imagine we're in a radar room Somewhere buried under the surface of Scotland people are earnestly making sure that the country is Information comes in We've got unidentified contacts There's three blips over the North Sea and they're moving west And back then before they had the computers they'd get a little bit of like a China graph or something and write it up There's people in this room in this bunker looking around trying to figure out what's going on trying to figure out if they're safe And they write information on the blackboard We give them an ID We don't know what these contacts are but now we can identify them We're currently okay with the events that are unfolding But let's put some more information on our blackboard So these contacts they seem to be Russian bombers In the Cold War this would be bad news But it's important news too So military people call this a recognized air picture Different people with different roles can see a consistent view They don't have to explain it in words to each other before they ask questions about how do we know these are There's no time for that And the technique came from the 1930s of the Royal Air Force in the United Kingdom but it was adopted worldwide They switched from light boards to technology Maybe some of you are wondering like okay this is air defense Like what's the link to the There's one easy segue I mentioned the The need to connect all of these systems together directly led to the invention of TCPIP which is kind of important But there is something else It's the blackboard architectural pattern Now there's three components in a blackboard which I'm going to explain in reverse order Controllers briefly Now give me a hands up if you know what controllers are in Kubernetes Okay yeah good We've got some folks who've heard of these things So controllers they act on what they know about your cluster to drive the actual state towards the desired state And the blackboard pattern before Kubernetes was a thing was already talking about this In Kubernetes we have controllers and we have operators And I mentioned operators because of the heritage the etymology We call them operators because they're like the people who loaded the tapes in your data center or fixed your web app at 3am The operator pattern is about making automation that does as good a job as the person who deploys your app Well controllers were originally the people who looked at the blackboard and did things But they're also the people who maintain the blackboard So in this pattern controllers write to the blackboard read from the blackboard So They are processes They're not people They're processes that manage knowledge on the blackboard Controllers are the way that knowledge gets added And different controllers react in different ways depending on what they see So I hope some of you are starting to see the parallels with Kubernetes In your cluster maybe you've got a crumb drop controller Probably not going to pass conformance if you don't And it's watching the blackboard It's watching the blackboard to see what happens to But also when the crumb drop controller makes a job well it writes to the blackboard Other things write back It sees what happened And the kubelet watches the same blackboard to find out what pops to run And I'm kind of laboring this point because I want to make it clear that it's true in air defense too You didn't just have one controller You had different jobs One controller might scrabble fighters And another one might notify fire stations And in the pattern that's called knowledge What do we know We put it on the blackboard There's distillation of So however it's represented this isn't a firehose of every fact we know It's not all of the radar data or all of the sample data for audio recognition It's distilled based on the raw events coming in Same in Kubernetes It's not every single byte coming down from the kubelet Controllers make sense of what they learn and they share a relevant summary And blackboards hold knowledge They're durable Controllers are what put the information on the blackboard and remove it If you've got a blackboard and the information is disappearing for some other reason that's a bug That's a fault The blackboard doesn't expire anything It's done And the source of truth can be external It often is So Kubernetes API server It is the blackboard I guess some of you are way ahead of me That's what I wanted Kubernetes yes it's a REST like API But actually the HTTP part is not the important detail in this architecture We've got these qualities of the blackboard It's got heterogeneous components Different things are looking at it The data store is completely separate from controllers at least logically And the whole architecture has a tolerance for partial knowledge It's not built around that And actually this place where I've got to in the talk I just wanted to set that background for my real point Because my real point is about security How do you secure this For air defense there's a trusted boundary The building perimeter You've got people whose job it is to make sure that everyone inside that boundary is authorized And I guess to stretch the analogy a little unreliable controllers are terminated and replaced And possibly there's a court martial So this talk is really about the secure blackboard pattern Would anyone like to give an example of a secure blackboard And I asked that question to make a little point There is this architectural pattern and it's established You can look up the papers and so on But there's very few examples of it except there's this thing that at this KCD UK we're all about Kubernetes And so Kubernetes is this almost unusual example of this architectural pattern that's really powerful and hardly ever used So that's my There's some more components to a secure blackboard Adding security means we now have five elements to think about And I say five I hope you thought about audit logs A secure cluster kind of depends on being able to audit what's happened as well And I'm going to talk about these extra details Even if you trust all of the controllers and components you might not Kubernetes has clients and they can write to the blackboard too That's how you interact with And we can't control what they want to do But we can restrict what they can do and that is essential So in the pattern a secure blackboard needs a way to limit who can write where who can do what And if you're in the talk I bet you can guess what I'm going to tell you Kubernetes provides namespaces Those are your primary isolation boundaries It's as if you've taken a real blackboard and you've pulled down a blind and said you can't see that You can't write to that And a bunch of you will know as well that out of the box vanilla Kubernetes makes security bypasses a bit too easy But because we've got those isolation boundaries and we've got other details the ingredients are there for locking it down So another aspect of Kubernetes security is about making sure that principles fancy word for users and but principles are kept apart and Kubernetes gives you the building blocks for this You can grant access to a specific API like Job You can grant access to specific resources like this particular cron job And in really recent Kubernetes you can even grant access based on does the thing have a particular value in a particular field So the out of box controls might not be enough but the ingredients are there So authentication and requiring authentication it kind of means you can trust your audit logs as well And if you go and look at what this architectural pattern means if any of you have the having gone to this don't trust me and go read the you'll see that audit logs are sort of a key element of the And if you can't trust your audit logs you definitely have a I guess this is where I mentioned I work for a security company and if you have that problem do come and talk to us So this is what the control plane looks like in terms of the containers and processes you need to run That's the most common diagram of a Kubernetes cluster And you add some nodes and you add some add ons put your own controllers in there and you start building a slick cloud platform Great Kubernetes architecture kind of follows its own design principles It's self consistent And what I mean is like the API server doesn't especially trust other things It doesn't trust the It doesn't trust other controllers to be doing a good job any more than it has to I'll give you an example Like the scheduler can have a look at nodes It can see all the It can query infrastructure resources look at pods You shouldn't give it access to anything else and typically you don't But actually this picture is not what I want you to leave here thinking about So here's a cron job in a namespace This could be a you know a view on a blackboard I was saying that those air defense controllers they didn't see everything on their screen They had a view on what they needed to see for their job When you've got that like one air control one controller air defense controller might not see that there's cities on the They don't need to see where the cities are for their job but the system knows We can draw what's important on the blackboard We can make views we can filter and we can restrict access so that people really can't see further Crucially and you'll know this but I want to link it to the pattern Nothing in Kubernetes nothing in this pattern depends on one element having access to the entire blackboard contents I'm also going to go back to I think Anna's in this talk So we opened this yesterday with Anna's talk on what Kubernetes is And I'm just borrowing this slide with her permission So she was talking about a workplace and Kubernetes being different people and communication tools for business I think this is a great analogy I really like it But to link it to my talk just imagine that the blackboard is what all these people are looking at So I'm going to The secure blackboard pattern has five elements and my thesis is that Kubernetes is actually the best known and best example of that pattern Kubernetes is much more than a blackboard security primitives and extension points let you and the control plane working for you make a secure auditable resilient blackboard for orchestrating your cloud native workload And it's also the Achilles heel You've got these APIs You've got certificate signing requests You've got role cluster or binding They're all written to the blackboard So with this pattern it's not like the analogy of an American Air Defense Center circa 1969 Because there you didn't use the radar screens to decide who can access the building But with Kubernetes the blackboard is your security boundary And securing it becomes incredibly important And making sure that security is built into your platform is essential for success And really that is my point Kubernetes is the secure blackboard pattern This is how I recommend people think about their cluster Think about what a Kubernetes is when you're modeling the security properties of it Because the strengths and the weaknesses fit that analogy really well Thank you for listening folks And perhaps we've got some time for
